body: Burlington Tuck Creek flood mitigation project restricts New Street lane for six months
description:
A single lane restriction will be in place on New Street for the next six months during water main replacement under Tuck Creek in Burlington. The Tuck Creek flood mitigation project is scheduled to continue from November through to May 2025 and includes replacing approximately 112 metres of water main — with 40 metres installed under Tuck Creek through bedrock using trenchless technology. The lane restriction will be in place on the westbound curb-lane on New Street between Woodview and Elwood roads. The new water main will be installed lower than existing infrastructure to allow future replacement and widening of the Tuck Street-New Street bridge next year. In August, engineering services director Scott Hamilton said this bridge did not contribute to July 2024 flooding, but its widening will help reduce future flooding risks. The project was awarded on Oct. 1 at a cost of just over $1.9 million to Vaughan-based KAPP Infrastructure Inc. For more information on the project, visit burlington.ca/newstwatermain.

body: 萬錦在加拿大最佳外賣城市中排名第五，僅次於溫哥華
description:
This story is part of a new initiative to provide content to our Chinese readers. You can find the English version here. 隨著外賣成為加拿大日常生活中越來越重要的一部分，新的研究揭示了在哪裏你可以找到最好的披薩、漢堡和雞翅。  你猜怎麼著？ 萬錦在全國外賣城市中排名第五，僅落後於排名第四的溫哥華。 多虧了像Uber Eats這樣的外賣應用，加拿大人現在只需動動手指就可以享受最喜歡的食物，而萬錦市的美食便利性和多樣性在這個領域大放異彩。Spincasino.ca通過分析可獲得性和可負擔性，揭示了加拿大最適合外賣的城市。 萬錦市憑藉多元的餐飲選擇脫穎而出。 這項研究從Uber Eats中提取了數據，考察了提供披薩、漢堡和雞翅等熱門外賣菜品的餐廳數量以及平均價格。萬錦在多樣性和便利性方面得分很高，為居民提供了豐富的美味選擇。 多倫多的怡陶碧谷名列全國外賣最佳城市榜首，其次是多倫多和士嘉堡。 一些有趣的研究結果 士嘉堡在披薩方面拔得頭籌，擁有447家披薩店，是全加拿大最多的城市，平均價格為14.85加元。 多倫多在漢堡和雞翅方面均領先，全市共有445家漢堡店和422家雞翅店。平均每個芝士漢堡的價格為15.07加元，而雞翅的價格為14.66加元。

body: Vaughan animal shelter hosting adoption clinic with reduced fees
description:
The Vaughan animal shelter is hosting an animal adoption clinic Sunday, Nov. 17 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. The local shelter, located at 70 Tigi Crt., Unit 47, has plenty of cats and dogs in its care that are looking for a new permanent home.  Residents can attend the community event without booking an appointment. Vaughan Animal Services (VAS) is offering reduced adoption fees during the event and will be charging $50 for cats and $100 for dogs. Kittens and puppies will also be available for the regular adoption fee of $175 for kittens and $275 for puppies. VAS says the fee covers the cost of rabies vaccines, sterilization and microchip implantation. For Vaughan residents, the fees include the first annual pet licence. Debit and credit cards will be accepted at the animal adoption clinic but not cash. The following criteria is required to adopt an animal at the clinic: Attendees looking to adopt a cat are reminded to bring a carrier to safely transport the feline. VAS says those looking to adopt dogs should bring household members to meet the animal, and once applications are approved, new dog owners will be notified within the week to book an appointment and pick up their new pet. Get a sneak peek of cats and dogs available for adoption here.

body: Magna International’s Neighbourhood Network kicks off holiday gift drive
description:
We’re sharing this information with you, even though we didn’t write it. It was provided by Neighbourhood Network. This copy was reviewed and edited by the Metroland editorial team. The countdown to the holiday season has already begun, and Neighbourhood Network’s elves are ready to spread joy through their annual Holiday Gift Drive!  Last year, this program supported more than 440 individuals in their partnered municipalities of Aurora, East Gwillimbury, Georgina, King Township, Newmarket, and Whitchurch-Stouffville. This year, with an increased need for support, they are gearing up to make an even greater impact. You can be a part of this initiative in two ways: sponsor a family or make a general donation. “We’re always moved by the community’s willingness to give,” shares Erin Cerenzia, manager of community relations. “This program is designed to make it easy for everyone to join in — whether you’re choosing items from our virtual lists or personally shopping for a family, each gift truly lights up someone’s holiday.” All sponsored families reside in Neighbourhood Network’s catchment area and are vetted through their partnered charitable organizations. Urgently needed donations include gift cards, new and unwrapped toys, winter wear, toiletries, and diapers, which are crucial for fulfilling the wishes of their 400-plus charitable partners. “For some families, even basic essentials are out of reach. Each donation, no matter the size, brings real hope and comfort to neighbours who are facing challenging times this season,” Cerenzia said. Donations can be dropped off at two locations until Dec. 11: The Holiday Gift Drive embodies the spirit of giving within our community. Your participation can make this season merry for your neighbours and leave a lasting impact. For more information, visit nnetwork.org/HGD. Neighbourhood Network is a department of Magna International that multiplies community giving and creates caring and vibrant neighbourhoods through promoting volunteerism, linking resources, and supporting local charities and agencies.

body: Ready for some winter fun in Vaughan? WinterFest returns to Canada’s Wonderland
description:
The holiday magic of WinterFest returns to Canada’s Wonderland for its fifth season on Nov. 16. The annual holiday event — featuring live shows, enchanted themed areas, millions of lights, and festive food — is open on select dates until Jan. 4, 2025.  “Get ready for the biggest, brightest holiday experience around,” said Phil Liggett, general manager in a news release. “WinterFest is a feel-good event for guests of all ages and brings the magic of the season to life. If you haven’t had a chance to see it, this is Canada’s Wonderland like you’ve never seen it before.” This year’s festivities include a nightly tree lighting ceremony, nine live shows, musical performances and interactive attractions like ice skating on Snow Flake Lake, photo ops with Elf on a Shelf and cookie decorating with Mrs. Claus.  Wonderland’s WinterFest returns with more than 40 attractions, including:  Tinker’s Toy Factory: An indoor show at Canterbury Theatre with music, acrobatics and an entertaining story about elf hijinks in Santa’s Workshop.  Rides: Guests can enjoy more than 20 rides, including the children’s rides in Charlie Brown’s Christmas Town, and other favourites like Thunder Run, Klockwerks, Psyclone and Sledge Hammer. Ice Skating on Snow Flake Lake: Attendees can glide down the ice on the shimmering, frozen lake in front of Wonder Mountain and surrounded by lit trees and holiday light projections. Advance online reservations are required. Nightly tree-lighting ceremony: A song-and-dance event on International Street where two 50-foot-tall Christmas trees are lit, and decorated with thousands of lights and ornaments.  Cool Yule Christmas: A high-energy, fun-filled show covering Christmas pop songs. Jack Frost’s Igloo Village: Guests can rent a cosy, private igloo for the evening with concierge food and beverage service. Four Drummers Drumming: Playful toy soldiers drum familiar favourites with the crowd. A PEANUTS™ Guide to Christmas: Guests can join Charlie Brown and the gang in an enjoyable singalong to celebrate the holidays. Elf on the Shelf: Santa’s favourite helper will keep an eye on guests and is happy to pose for photos. Christmas Market: A Christmas market featuring local artisan vendors, food and amazing gift ideas.  Find a full list of shows and attractions, operating hours, tickets and reservations for WinterFest 2024 here.

body: Here’s a list of road closures, disruptions in Vaughan for November 2024
description:
Vaughan is undergoing several road closures and disruptions this month.  Vaughan is installing a new water main on Islington Avenue in the Kleinburg Village. The city says daily closures are underway to complete the work until Nov. 15, from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m., and that access to residences and businesses along Islington Avenue will not be impacted.  The southbound traffic on Islington Avenue from Highway 27 will be redirected south on Highway 27, while southbound traffic from Treelawn Boulevard will be redirected north to Highway 27. Northbound traffic on Islington Avenue may also be redirected west to Nashville Road. Vaughan adds that work may take place overnight to minimize disruptions to businesses and pedestrians and that, during the day, flag persons and detour signs will be in place to guide traffic.  A road closure has been taking place on Thornridge Drive, between Yonge Street and Elizabeth Street, since Oct. 28 from 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. on weekdays and will continue until Nov. 22, to safely complete utility installation work for the Yonge North Subway Extension. The road is accessible by commuters for the remainder of the day. Metrolinx says signage and barriers are present to guide travellers through the detour routes. Residents can expect noise and vibration from construction vehicles and noticeable equipment while work is underway. Additional improvements to the off-leash dog area in Concord/Thornhill Regional Park located at 299 Racco Pkwy. is undergoing additional improvements, scheduled to begin in late October and last approximately four weeks while weather permits throughout November 2024. The city says construction includes electrical and light pole installation, grading, fence and gate installation and paving. A temporary shared-use area — for large and small dogs — will be available in the park during this time and signage and barriers will be in place to guide visitors.  Check out Vaughan’s full list of closures and disruptions here.

body: Got mail? Here are other mail and shipping options for Canadians as potential Canada Post strike looms
description:
As the threat of a possible work stoppage at Canada Post looms ahead of the holidays, you may be wondering what other shipping services are available to you. There are numerous options actually.  Canada Post and the union representing its postal workers are negotiating a new collective agreement. While neither side has issued a notice of strike or lockout, both parties are in a legal position to do so. They must provide a minimum of 72 hours’ notice before a labour disruption can occur. Canada Post has said the threat of this labour disruption has already impacted its business, as volumes and revenue are down ahead of what’s usually a busy holiday shipping season. So, if you are feeling nervous about using Canada’s postal service, even as it continues to deliver the mail, below are some options available to you for shipping within Canada and internationally. U.S.-based global shipping company FedEx offers Canada-wide and international shipping services. It consists of express delivery and includes next-day delivery to most metropolitan areas, to standard ground and freight services. If you need to send items to the United States or other international markets, FedEx has standard shipping and express options, including next-day shipping to many locations within the U.S. More information is available at fedex.com. While Canada Post is the majority owner of Purolator, the workers at this Canadian courier company are represented by a different union than those at Canada Post. So any strike action at Canada Post will not impact Purolator’s services. The shipping company can deliver packages to, from and within Canada and to more than 210 countries. With more than 2,500 authorized shipping agents in Canada, finding a location is as easy as finding a local pharmacy. More information is available at purolator.com. Another U.S.-based company, UPS provides global shipping and logistics services. Canadians can use it for domestic and international shipping, including same-day delivery options as well as freight shipping options. The company also offers Saturday delivery in Canada. More information is available at ups.com. What launched as a local delivery business in the Toronto area in the 1980s has grown to become a courier transportation and logistics company serving all of Canada as well as in the U.S., with a focus on serving health-care, IT and retail businesses. More information is available at appleexpress.com. The DHL international courier service provider, which is owned by Germany’s Deutsche Post, provides services for international shipping from Canada. DHL has document and parcel services for all shippers, as well as retailer and volume shipping and cargo shipping for businesses. More information is available at dhl.com. ShippingChimp provides shipping services anywhere in Canada and the U.S., as well as to destinations in other parts of the world, with a focus on eCommerce shipping solutions for small businesses. More information is available at shippingchimp.com. DTDC Express Canada, which is part of India’s largest parcel delivery network, is a courier specializing in cross-border eCommerce services. It has a direct presence in 21 countries, including the U.S. and U.K., and with operations, through associates, in many other countries. More information is available at canada.dtdc.com. Quebec-based last-kilometre logistics company Intelcom, which operates as Dragonfly outside Quebec, utilizes independent delivery partners to handle up to 600,000 daily deliveries in 10 provinces and two territories. The company has numerous stations in Ontario. More information is available at intelcom.ca.

body: Ontario, Canada recalls: Space heaters sold on Amazon, Wolf griddle, lip balm, Johnsonville sausages, bread sold at Sobeys, FreshCo, Foodland, Metro, Shoppers Drug Mart and more
description:
Thousands of space heaters sold on Amazon, battery packs, various bread and buns sold at major Ontario grocery stores, Wolf griddle, Johnsonville sausages, crispy rice snacks, pregnancy multivitamins and more have recently been recalled by Health Canada and the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA).  The CFIA issued a recall on Nov. 1 for Johnsonville brand Smoked Beef Sausages and Smoked Beef Cheddar Cheese Sausages due incorrect best-before date. The sausages were distributed in Alberta, British Columbia, New Brunswick, Ontario and Quebec.  CFIA tells people not to use sell, serve or distribute the affected products. The CFIA has issued a recall notice on Oct. 30 for an Italian cheese distributed in Ontario and other Canadian provinces. The Dal Molise brand Burratina soft Italian fresh cheese with creamy centre is being recalled due to “generic E. coli.” Dal Molise brand Burratina Soft Italian Fresh Cheese with Creamy Center recalled due to  Health Canada has issued a recall notice on Nov. 7 for various models of GoveeLife and Govee smart electric space heaters, which were sold through Amazon, due to fire and burn hazards.  The company reported approximately 48,584 units were sold in Canada and approximately 512,500 units were sold in the U.S. from October 2021 through May 2024. As of Oct. 28, the company has received seven reports of overheating in Canada and no report of injuries. In the U.S., the company has received 106 reports of overheating and one report of a “minor burn injury.” There has been one report of a “minor burn injury” in the U.S., and seven reports of overheating  The CFIA has issued a recall notice for various popular bread brands including Country Harvest, Deli World, D’Italiano, Giant Value, Great Value, no name, President’s Choice and Wonder due to “pieces of metal.” The products were sold through Metro, Shoppers Drug Mart, Amazon, Real Canadian Superstore, No Frills, Zehrs, Foodland, FreshCo, and Sobeys locations, as well as through Voilà fulfilment centres. The products have been distributed in Ontario, Newfoundland and Labrador and Quebec. More than three dozen products have been impacted. A full list can be found by visiting the full CFIA recall notice published on Nov. 1. On Oct. 28, a voluntary recall involving Wonder Brands Inc., was issued for bread and bun products sold at Costco and Giant Tiger.  Bread products under the brand names Compliments, Dempster’s, Harvest Gold, Pom and Sunshine involving the firm Bimbo Canada were also recalled on Nov. 5. Country Harvest, Deli World, D’Italiano, Giant Value, Great Value, no name, President’s Choice  The CFIA issued a recall notice on Nov. 6 for Hestars Temple Street Crispy Rice (“Corn flavour”) 108-gram package with UPC code 6 970798 321981 was recalled. It impacts all codes where milk is not declared on the label. The recall was triggered by a consumer complaint. CFIA says there’s been one reported reaction associated with the consumption of this product. The impacted products were distributed in Nova Scotia, Ontario and Quebec. The affected product is being recalled from the marketplace because it contains milk that is not declared on the label. Check to see if you have recalled products, don’t consume recalled products to which you are allergic or sensitive as they may cause a serious or life-threatening reaction. Do not serve, use, sell or distribute recalled products. Recalled products should be thrown out or returned to the location where they were purchased.  Hestars brand Temple Street Crispy Rice (“Corn flavor”) recalled due to undeclared milk.  Health Canada issued a recall notice on Nov. 7 involving the Quad Lock MAG Battery Pack (QMA-BPK-5000), which is a wireless portable power bank, equipped with chargeable lithium-ion batteries. The battery packs are black and measure approximately 83 by 60 by 16 millimetres. The recall notice indicates the battery pack can experience overheating, melting or heat-related deformation posing a fire hazard to consumers. The company reported that 1,582 units of the affected products were sold in Canada and 13,706 were sold in the United States between April 2023 to September 2024. As of Nov. 1, the company has received no reports of overheating in Canada, and no reports of injuries. In the United States, the company has received three reports of overheating and no reports of injuries. This is a joint recall with Health Canada, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission and Quad Lock. Health Canada recommends people “immediately stop using the product” and contact Quad Lock for a refund or store credit. “Dispose of the product by contacting your municipality for instructions on how to safely transport and dispose of lithium-ion batteries,” the health agency says. Contact your municipality for instructions on how to safely transport and dispose of lithium-ion batteries. Batteries are considered hazardous waste. Do not place them in household garbage. For more information, consumers can contact Quad Lock by telephone toll-free at 833-362-9855, from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. PT Monday through Friday, by email at recall@quadlock.com.au or online. Quad Lock MAG Battery Pack recalled due to fire hazard. Person holding the battery pack. This recall involves Wolf dual fuel range with infrared griddle available in three sizes with various configurations (including with a stainless steel, white or black door). The serial and model numbers are printed on the rating plate underneath the top of the oven. The recalled ranges have serial numbers from 18517201 to 18868311. Wolf Dual Fuel range with infrared griddle recalled due to burn and fire hazards. Serial numbers and models impacted. The recall listing explains a spill of liquids (such as a boiling over) can cause a short-circuit in a plug of an electronic component which controls the griddle. “The griddle can turn on unexpectedly, posing a burn or fire hazard to consumers,” the recall notice says.  This is a joint recall with Health Canada, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission and Wolf Appliance, Inc. Wolf Dual Fuel range with infrared griddle recalled due to burn and fire hazards. As of Oct. 22, the company has received three reports of griddles turning on in Canada and no reports of injuries. In the U.S., the company has received 33 reports of griddles turning on and no reports of injuries. Consumers should “immediately stop using” the recalled item and contact Wolf Appliance to schedule a free repair in their home. For more information, consumers can contact Wolf Appliance by telephone at 1-800-200-7820 from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. CT Monday through Friday, by email at support@wolfappliance.com or online at www.wolfappliance.com/recall or www.subzero-wolf.com and click on “Important Recall Information” at the bottom of the website for more information. Health Canada has issued a recall notice for two JAMP Pharma pregnancy multivitamins as the impacted lots “exceed the acceptable intake limit for N-nitroso-folic acid.” The recalling company is listed as JAMP Pharma Corporation. The recall notice indicates the supplements were distributed nationally, according to the recall noticed posted on Nov. 6. Health Canada says products were distributed in Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Labrador, Ontario, Quebec and Saskatchewan. JAMP Pharma Pregnancy Multivitamin and JAMP Pharma Pregnancy Multivitamin Folic 5 are impacted  Health Canada has issued a national recall for Dead Down Wind Broad Spectrum SPF 30 Odourless Lip Balm because it was sold without market authorization. The “unauthorized product” was sold through Amazon and Cabela’s. The Health Canada recall notice indicates the product was sold “without market authorization,” namely a drug identification number in Canada. Health Canada says product was sold ‘without market authorization.’ To see all recalls posted visit the Government of Canada’s recall list featuring recalls issued by Health Canada and the Canadian Food Inspection Agency.

body: Typical fall weekend will run cool and warm for southern Ontario from Nov. 9-10
description: The “typical ebb and flow of warmth and cooler temperatures through the fall” will lean to the cooler side for most of southern Ontario on Saturday. After a forecasted high in the low teens on Friday, the overnight temperature into Saturday was forecasted to drop to 0 C, with Saturday’s high only 7 C amid clear skies for Pearson airport in Mississauga. That’s actually pretty close to normal for this time of year, with Environment Canada listing the normal high at 8 C and low at 2 C for Pearson. But another system coming in on Sunday will again shoot temperatures back a bit above normal (10 C at Pearson), along with a chance of showers. That system will roll through starting Sunday morning in the southwestern portion of the province, said Environment Canada meteorologist Steven Flisfeder. “The further east you are, it’ll be more into the afternoon, evening,” he said. “But we’re not expecting too much precipitation with it. It’s very dry in the middle atmosphere, so it’s very likely that a lot of that moisture associated with it will even evaporate as it falls, so not expecting too much in terms of actual accumulation.” That warmth will stick around on Monday (11 C at Pearson) before yet another system will come and drop temperatures back down to normal. It’s pretty much the pattern for most of southern Ontario according to Environment Canada forecasts, which you can check here for Hamilton, St. Catharines, Peterborough, Barrie and Ottawa. Southwestern Ontario is forecasted to remain above normal all weekend, according to the Environment Canada forecast for Windsor, London and Sarnia. Top stories delivered to your inbox. Norm Nelson is an online editor with Metroland. Email nnelson@metroland.com to reach him.

Dal Molise brand Burratina Soft Italian Fresh Cheese with Creamy Center recalled due to "generic E. coli." Dal Molise brand Burratina Soft Italian Fresh Cheese with Creamy Center recalled due to "generic E. coli." Health Canada has issued a recall notice on Nov. 7 for various models of GoveeLife and Govee smart electric space heaters, which were sold through Amazon, due to fire and burn hazards.  The company reported approximately 48,584 units were sold in Canada and approximately 512,500 units were sold in the U.S. from October 2021 through May 2024. As of Oct. 28, the company has received seven reports of overheating in Canada and no report of injuries. In the U.S., the company has received 106 reports of overheating and one report of a “minor burn injury.” There has been one report of a “minor burn injury” in the U.S., and seven reports of overheating in Canada.  There has been one report of a “minor burn injury” in the U.S., and seven reports of overheating in Canada.  The CFIA has issued a recall notice for various popular bread brands including Country Harvest, Deli World, D'Italiano, Giant Value, Great Value, no name, President's Choice and Wonder due to “pieces of metal.” The products were sold through Metro, Shoppers Drug Mart, Amazon, Real Canadian Superstore, No Frills, Zehrs, Foodland, FreshCo, and Sobeys locations, as well as through Voilà fulfilment centres. The products have been distributed in Ontario, Newfoundland and Labrador and Quebec. More than three dozen products have been impacted. A full list can be found by visiting the full CFIA recall notice published on Nov. 1. On Oct. 28, a voluntary recall involving Wonder Brands Inc., was issued for bread and bun products sold at Costco and Giant Tiger.  Bread products under the brand names Compliments, Dempster's, Harvest Gold, Pom and Sunshine involving the firm Bimbo Canada were also recalled on Nov. 5. Country Harvest, Deli World, D'Italiano, Giant Value, Great Value, no name, President's Choice and Wonder products have been recalled. Country Harvest, Deli World, D'Italiano, Giant Value, Great Value, no name, President's Choice and Wonder products have been recalled. The CFIA issued a recall notice on Nov. 6 for Hestars Temple Street Crispy Rice ("Corn flavour") 108-gram package with UPC code 6 970798 321981 was recalled. It impacts all codes where milk is not declared on the label. The recall was triggered by a consumer complaint. CFIA says there's been one reported reaction associated with the consumption of this product. The impacted products were distributed in Nova Scotia, Ontario and Quebec. The affected product is being recalled from the marketplace because it contains milk that is not declared on the label. Check to see if you have recalled products, don't consume recalled products to which you are allergic or sensitive as they may cause a serious or life-threatening reaction. Do not serve, use, sell or distribute recalled products. Recalled products should be thrown out or returned to the location where they were purchased.  Hestars brand Temple Street Crispy Rice ("Corn flavor") recalled due to undeclared milk.  Health Canada issued a recall notice on Nov. 7 involving the Quad Lock MAG Battery Pack (QMA-BPK-5000), which is a wireless portable power bank, equipped with chargeable lithium-ion batteries. The battery packs are black and measure approximately 83 by 60 by 16 millimetres. The recall notice indicates the battery pack can experience overheating, melting or heat-related deformation posing a fire hazard to consumers. The company reported that 1,582 units of the affected products were sold in Canada and 13,706 were sold in the United States between April 2023 to September 2024. As of Nov. 1, the company has received no reports of overheating in Canada, and no reports of injuries. In the United States, the company has received three reports of overheating and no reports of injuries. This is a joint recall with Health Canada, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission and Quad Lock. Health Canada recommends people "immediately stop using the product" and contact Quad Lock for a refund or store credit. "Dispose of the product by contacting your municipality for instructions on how to safely transport and dispose of lithium-ion batteries," the health agency says. Contact your municipality for instructions on how to safely transport and dispose of lithium-ion batteries. Batteries are considered hazardous waste. Do not place them in household garbage. For more information, consumers can contact Quad Lock by telephone toll-free at 833-362-9855, from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. PT Monday through Friday, by email at recall@quadlock.com.au or online. Quad Lock MAG Battery Pack recalled due to fire hazard. Person holding the battery pack. This recall involves Wolf dual fuel range with infrared griddle available in three sizes with various configurations (including with a stainless steel, white or black door). The serial and model numbers are printed on the rating plate underneath the top of the oven. The recalled ranges have serial numbers from 18517201 to 18868311. Wolf Dual Fuel range with infrared griddle recalled due to burn and fire hazards. Serial numbers and models impacted. The recall listing explains a spill of liquids (such as a boiling over) can cause a short-circuit in a plug of an electronic component which controls the griddle. "The griddle can turn on unexpectedly, posing a burn or fire hazard to consumers," the recall notice says.  This is a joint recall with Health Canada, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission and Wolf Appliance, Inc. Wolf Dual Fuel range with infrared griddle recalled due to burn and fire hazards. As of Oct. 22, the company has received three reports of griddles turning on in Canada and no reports of injuries. In the U.S., the company has received 33 reports of griddles turning on and no reports of injuries. Consumers should "immediately stop using" the recalled item and contact Wolf Appliance to schedule a free repair in their home. For more information, consumers can contact Wolf Appliance by telephone at 1-800-200-7820 from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. CT Monday through Friday, by email at support@wolfappliance.com or online at www.wolfappliance.com/recall or www.subzero-wolf.com and click on “Important Recall Information” at the bottom of the website for more information. Health Canada has issued a recall notice for two JAMP Pharma pregnancy multivitamins as the impacted lots "exceed the acceptable intake limit for N-nitroso-folic acid." The recalling company is listed as JAMP Pharma Corporation. The recall notice indicates the supplements were distributed nationally, according to the recall noticed posted on Nov. 6. Health Canada says products were distributed in Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Labrador, Ontario, Quebec and Saskatchewan. JAMP Pharma Pregnancy Multivitamin and JAMP Pharma Pregnancy Multivitamin Folic 5 are impacted by the recall. JAMP Pharma Pregnancy Multivitamin and JAMP Pharma Pregnancy Multivitamin Folic 5 are impacted by the recall. Health Canada has issued a national recall for Dead Down Wind Broad Spectrum SPF 30 Odourless Lip Balm because it was sold without market authorization. The “unauthorized product” was sold through Amazon and Cabela's. The Health Canada recall notice indicates the product was sold “without market authorization,” namely a drug identification number in Canada. Health Canada says product was sold 'without market authorization.' Health Canada says product was sold 'without market authorization.' To see all recalls posted visit the Government of Canada's recall list featuring recalls issued by Health Canada and the Canadian Food Inspection Agency. Top stories delivered to your inbox. body: Still want to see Taylor Swift's Toronto Eras Tour? Try winning concert tickets with these new contests
description: You still have a chance to win some Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour tickets in Toronto. Six sold-out shows are happening at the Rogers Centre from Nov. 14 to 23, and if you didn’t get your hands on tickets, there are still a few ways to win some.
